claim: A modest aspiration is more dangerous than a lofty one. Playing to participate leads to mediocrity and unwillingness to make the tough choices and investments required for victory.
rationale: Companies that aspire merely to 'still make money' get outcompeted by rivals who aspire to win the segment. Saturn failed because its aspiration was too modest to justify sustained investment needed to keep up with Toyota, Honda, and Nissan who were playing to win.

claim: Strategy is not a vision, a plan, or an optimization of the status quo. It's an integrated set of five choices: winning aspiration, where to play, how to win, capabilities needed, and management systems required.
rationale: The five choices flow from one to the next, with choices at the top setting context for choices below, and choices at the bottom influencing and refining those above. Each level must align with and reinforce choices made above and below.

claim: There are only two ways to create sustainable competitive advantage: cost leadership (lower cost structure than competitors) or differentiation (distinctively more valuable offering commanding price premium).
rationale: Cost leadership gives greater margin to underprice competitors or reinvest in reinforcing position. Differentiation creates unique offering a specific customer group pays more for. There can only be one true low-cost leader in an industry.

claim: Ask 'What would have to be true for this possibility to be a fantastic choice?' This shifts conversation from arguing about what is true to collaboratively exploring the logic behind different options.
rationale: The reverse engineering process turns strategy from a political battle into a collaborative search. Test the biggest barrier first—if a possibility fails its most critical test, discard it without wasting resources testing other conditions.

claim: Competitive advantage comes not from a single strength but from a mutually reinforcing set of activities—an activity system—that is difficult for competitors to replicate.
rationale: While a competitor might match one capability (e.g., L'Oréal's branding), none can easily replicate the entire integrated system. The activities must be not only consistent but reinforce one another, making the whole stronger than the sum of parts.

claim: Trying to be all things to all people results in underserving everyone. A choice to serve 'everyone' is a losing choice. Even Apple doesn't serve all markets equally.
rationale: Strategy is about focus. The 'where to play' choice must narrow the competitive field. Companies that fail to choose spread resources thin and cannot create distinctive value for any segment.

claim: Trying to buy your way out by acquiring a company in a more attractive industry rarely works. A firm unable to win in its current game is unlikely to win in a new one.
rationale: Attractive assets are expensive and often require entirely different capabilities. The acquisition trap assumes the grass is greener elsewhere rather than addressing fundamental capability gaps that would persist in any industry.

claim: Companies suffer from marketing myopia by defining their business by products they make rather than consumer need they meet. A powerful aspiration must be centered on the consumer, not the product.
rationale: Defining business as 'we make smartphones' versus 'we connect people' leads to different strategic possibilities. P&G's home-care doesn't aspire to make strongest cleanser—it aspires to 'reinvent cleaning experiences,' leading to Swiffer and Febreze.

claim: A strategy that only works if your rivals do nothing is dangerous. You must analyze how competitors will likely react to your choices before committing.
rationale: Before P&G launched concentrated Joy dish soap in Japan, the team modeled likely competitive responses. They concluded competitors would be slow to abandon existing profitable lines, giving Joy a crucial window to establish a foothold.

claim: Attack along the line of least resistance. Build a powerful brand before taking on incumbents directly by entering through less-contested segments or adjacent categories first.
rationale: Febreze avoided direct fight in crowded air freshener category. They introduced odor-eliminating technology as a laundry additive first, then fabric refresher, and only later as air deodorizer—building brand strength before confronting incumbents.

claim: Don't accept traditional industry segmentation. Look for new ways to segment based on geography, consumer needs, or channels. Creating new segments can seize market leadership from entrenched competitors.
rationale: For years toothpaste was segmented by cavity prevention only. Colgate seized market leadership by creating 'healthy mouth' segment with Colgate Total. P&G's Crest had to fundamentally rethink the industry map to compete.

claim: P&G's Olay created 'masstige' category—premium product at $18.99 in mass-market stores—transforming a struggling $800M brand into $2.5B leader by targeting women 35+ seeing first signs of aging.
rationale: Oil of Olay was derisively known as 'Oil of Old Lady.' Team made integrated choices: new name, new segment, technologically superior product fighting 'seven signs of aging,' prestige packaging at mass retail. Price signaled value to prestige shoppers and quality to mass shoppers.

claim: GM's Saturn failed because its aspiration was merely to participate and 'still make money' against Japanese imports, while Toyota, Honda, and Nissan aspired to win the small-car segment.
rationale: Saturn was launched as a defensive move to compete. The modest goal couldn't justify sustained investment needed to keep up with competitors playing to win. Playing to participate leads to mediocrity.

claim: P&G and Clorox created Glad joint venture instead of head-on competition. P&G provided technology and R&D; Clorox handled manufacturing, marketing, sales. P&G got 20% stake; Glad became billion-dollar brand.
rationale: P&G remembered painful failure of Citrus Hill orange juice crushed by entrenched Minute Maid and Tropicana despite superior technology. The innovative business model leveraged each company's strengths without costly market war.

claim: P&G's Bounty stopped global expansion to focus only on North America where it could be profitable leader, then segmented into three products for distinct user types: core, soft-seekers, and value-strength buyers.
rationale: Misguided global expansion had drained resources from core market. Business was structurally unattractive in most of the world due to overcapacity and private-label dominance. Clear segmentation allowed Bounty to dominate premium end by tailoring to specific needs.
